ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.
M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Increasing energy and interest in activities
Notes: 1 = Not at all;2 = A little bit;3 = Somewhat;4 = Quite a bit;5 = Very Much

ElementDescription: Improving social relations, such as doing more social activities with friends and family members
Notes: 1 = Not at all;2 = A little bit;3 = Somewhat;4 = Quite a bit;5 = Very Much

ElementDescription: Reducing disturbing and unusual experiences, such as hallucinations and delusions
Notes: 1 = Not at all;2 = A little bit;3 = Somewhat;4 = Quite a bit;5 = Very Much

ElementDescription: Reducing confusion and difficulty concentrating resulting in difficulty paying attention or thinking clearly
Notes: 1 = Not at all;2 = A little bit;3 = Somewhat;4 = Quite a bit;5 = Very Much

ElementDescription: Reducing medication side effects, such as feeling fidgety, restless, or stiff
Notes: 1 = Not at all;2 = A little bit;3 = Somewhat;4 = Quite a bit;5 = Very Much

ElementDescription: Increasing productive activities, such as having a job, going to school, or doing chores such as shopping or cleaning the house
Notes: 1 = Not at all;2 = A little bit;3 = Somewhat;4 = Quite a bit;5 = Very Much
e.g., Baseline, 6-Month Follow Up, Year 2, Daily
